events.name: Make-a-thon: Create for a Cause
events.about:
Overview

Make-a-thon: Create for a Cause is a fun day for makers, artisans, crafters, and tinkerers to come together as a community and make gifts for underprivileged families for the holidays. You'll get to mingle with other creative creators and make things that will be donated to Toys for Tots (toys) or the Salvation Army (non-toys). 

  • 11:00am: Arrival: People start arriving and begin their projects.
  • 11:30am: Welcome!: Just a quick hello and welcome to everyone.
  • Noon: Lunch: We will be offering pizza and beverages for people at the event.
  • 1pm-5pm: Create:  Continue making and mingling with other makers.  
FREE FOOD, BEER/HOLIDAY BEVERAGES, & NON-ALCOHOLIC DRINKS will be provided!
WANT TO COME FOR FREE? See below section, 'get support & sponsorship from your community'.

What to Make?

You can make whatever you like as long as it is appropriate as a holiday gift for less privileged individuals or families. We recommend toys since we are collaborating with Toys for Tots, and if you decide to do so, see below for guidelines on handmade toys. You can make toys, clothes or jewelry, cards, electronics, educational items, or anything you feel inspired to make! Unleash your creativity!

BYOM:

This event is 'Bring Your Own Materials'. Because you will have the flexibility to make whatever you want however you would like, we suggest bringing your own materials for the project. 

Get Support & Sponsorship from Your Community:

If you want to get friends or families to sponsor you for the materials for the event,

you can use CrowdTilt (see example)

OR you can have them purchase a gift card from Joann's here .

TAX WRITE-OFF: For your materials contribution, you can get a tax-write off since the items will be donated to charity. We will have forms for you and any of your contributors at the event.

 

Plan on Toy Making? Please read the guidelines:

"6.9 Homemade Toys. Of growing concern, is the donation of homemade toys, and whether or not Toys for Tots will continue to accept such toys, even though they may not have undergone the new testing process required for toys. The Foundation is taking the position that since homemade toymakers are not producing toys for the purposes of making a profit and have no reason to cut corners to increase profit margins or reduce their inventory, and that the toys are generally safe with minimal moving parts that could cause injury, that we will continue to accept homemade toys.  In doing so, there are three layers of safety that must be in place to ensure this policy can continue.

  •  Layer One: Toy makers must understand the requirement that homemade toys be safe (no small parts; rounded edges; lead-free paint; etc.); 
  • Layer Two: Toys for Tots coordinators (and their volunteer assistants) must take steps to ensure the makers are informed of the Layer One requirement, carefully inspect homemade toys when they are donated, AND make every effort to distribute such toys appropriately; and
  • Layer Three: Parents must ensure that any toy given to them to, in turn, present to their child, must be age appropriate." [Guidelines from: Toys for Tots]

Toy or Item Drop-Off?

If you only have time to drop-off a toy or gift, feel free to stop by and drop off items. If you plan to stay for longer, we will ask you to purchase a ticket so that we can manage our capacity. The drop-off HOURS will be 11am-5pm (same as the event).

Who Are We Supporting?

More Info: Toys for Tots               

More Info: Salvation Army 

In Collaboration With:

Project Society

Project Society is empowering a community of crafters and makers to come together and make items as well as earn money doing what they love. If you want to find out more about the opportunities as the PS team stitches things together, please sign up here.

Citizen Space 

Citizen Space is a coworking space in SF, and San Jose.The idea of Citizen Space is to take the best elements of a coffee shop (social, energetic, creative) and of a workspace (productive, functional) and combine them to give indie workers the chance to have their own, affordable space. 

AngelHack 

AngelHack unites developers around the world for a hackathon competition, where they can learn developer tools, start new companies, and win prizes and funding for their ideas.

Sponsorfied

We’re building the worlds largest database of brands, and connecting them with amazing sponsorship opportunities.

SPONSORSHIP:

If you would like to sponsor or have your company represented at this event, please contact: info@projectsociety.com .

FUTURE MAKE-A-THONS or Making Events?

If you are interested in organizing, hosting, collaborating, suggesting, or participating in future Make-a-thons, please contact us at info@projectsociety.com .

QUESTIONS or CONCERNS?

 If you have questions or concerns, please email info@projectsociety.com.

events.name: BeMyApp World Cup San Francisco
events.about:
BeMyApp WeekEnd is a three-day mobile app development competition taking place around the world since June 2010. The event’s goal is to foster a global community of entrepreneurs and to be a medium for team-formation and agile product development.

Hackathon with a spirit, BeMyApp aspires to promote an encounter between imagination and execution, where competition and collaboration go hand in hand.

The App Challenge

Follow mobile app news
& updates by BeMyApp

  •  Facebook
  •  Twitter
  •  bemyapp.com

Registered idea generators are given 1 minute to pitch an app concept to a tech audience on day one. Attending engineers and designers preselect the best ideas that will be developed into applications during the weekend. Teams are formed around the most promising projects and the competition is on. By Sunday evening, all competing teams should have a working prototype to demo in front of the panel of Judges.

 

The World Cup


Examples and Past 
Success Stories

  • Namerick
  • JesterChess
  • Starjar
  • Kinvolved
  • Lalilala
  • Deezy
  • Ujoolt
  • FoodReporter
  • PostrWall

The BeMyApp World Cup is open to all mobile platforms - both native and html5 apps - and will take place in 4 cities around the world: San Francisco, Singapore, Paris and Berlin.

A panel of judges in each city will nominate the best local app to continue in the finals and BeMyApp will be launching a 48hrs worldwide vote to nominate the Global Winner. The best prize you'll get are the connections you forge and the challenges you conquer. That said, we've got some pretty sweet cherry-on-top prizes planned and more are coming up too, so stay tuned for the updates!

 

Schedule

FRIDAY 

7pm - Opening

8pm - Idea Pitches

9pm - Team Creation

10pm - Brainstorming and First Lines of Code

1am - Closing

SATURDAY

9am - Opening

12pm - First Video CheckPoint

12am - Closing

SUNDAY

9am - Opening

12pm - Second Video CheckPoint

7pm - First Demos Presented

9pm - Winner Announcement (public)

-----

MONDAY, DECEMBER 10

9am - Online vote opening

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 12

8am - BeMyApp World Cup winner announcement

 
Want to join in but have questions?  Read on...
 
What do I need to be an idea generator?
You can be anyone with an app idea who wants to build a team and a prototype. Plan to dedicate the whole weekend, help and lead your team. We would like to encourage original and innovative ideas that will be build from scratch, so please bring something fresh to pitch!

What platforms can I develop for?
Any! Whether it’s an iPhone, Android, HTML5, Windows Phone app or a tablet app, we’re there to support you in building it!

Do I need to have a certain level of experience to get involved?
No, the event is about learning as well as applying your skills so you can get involved no matter how experienced you are.

What’s expected of me over the weekend?
You’ll get most out of the weekend by joining a team and building a working prototype of a mobile app. Please, plan to dedicate the whole weekend as your team will need you.

What should I bring?
Your enthusiasm, your portable computer, the mobile device you’re building for and your camera to immortalize the making of your application!

What is the judging criteria for the apps?
The apps will be judged on their stickiness, innovation, business potential and execution.

Who owns the apps created?
The apps are owned solely by their creators – we’ll provide you with some terms which you can use so your team knows where they all stand. Do note that we do not get involved legally so it is important that you discuss this with your team before you start on the prototype so everyone is clear on ownership.

Got more questions or interested in sponsoring? Please, get in touch with vera at bemyapp dot com!

events.name: RHoK Global December 2012: San Francisco, CA
events.about:
Join us for the Random Hacks of Kindness San Francisco Hackathon December 1st and 2nd 2012

RHoK Kick Off Reception Friday November 30th from 7:00-9:00pm 

Enjoy wine, beer, light bites and meet representatives from Google, Yahoo, Microsoft and NASA while we discuss the subject matters and logistics for the hackathon.

RHoK Global December 2012-San Francisco Saturday December 1st starting at 9:00am and ending Sunday December 2nd at 4:00pm

RHoK is a community of innovators building practical open technology to make the world a better place.  Come be a part of the Bay Area community and participate in one of the most exciting hackathons in the world!

What is a hackathon?

A hackathon is a gathering of technically skilled individuals focusing on collaborative efforts to address a challenge, issue, or goal. They usually run from several hours to weeks, and can include rigid structure or organic emergence.

What makes RHoK special?

Random Hacks of Kindness is a simultaneous global hackathon which addresses issues of disaster and humanitarian response. Local subject matter experts are brought in to guide the developers in relevant issues and to further the use of developed tools after the event.

What makes GWOB’s RHoK even specialer?

Geeks Without Bounds brings a year’s worth of experience in facilitating unconferences and hackathons to these events, as well as heavy involvement in the Volunteer Technology Community (VTC). We set expectations and limitations in regards to what responders will be able to learn on short notice under stress and what networks and power situations are like.

Both the reception and hackathon will take place at Voxeo Labs @ NextSpace 1 Hallidie Plaza, 2nd Floor in the Union Square District of downtown San Francisco.

Organized By

 

 

Sponsored By

           

Media Partners

events.name: Startup (Military) Veterans Day Weekend/Hackathon + Basic Training!!
events.about:
JOIN US!!!!

Calling all returning military veterans of Iraq & Afghanistan service AND the tech community in the SF Bay Area!

The Startup Veteran’s Day Weekend/Hackathon –

Join VetsinTech,  and Co-Chair Craig Newmark

Keynote Speaker - TBD VIP

NOTE: All meals are provided!!

For more info, schedule, speakers, sponsors and more (TBD)...

visit http://vetsintech.co/veterans-day-weekend-hackathon/

Our Objective: to support our returning bay area veterans - thru education, re-integration, and by connecting to the tech ecosystem in SF Bay Area!

In this two-day event the tech community in SF will come together to support our returning Iraq/Afghan veterans.  Teams of approximately 5-10 people will be formed with a variety of skills -the vets can have the idea, help with business plan, marketing or just sit in to audit/participate for educational purposes – vet coding skills are NOT required - however developers from the tech community are encouraged to attend!

Additional information can be found at www.vetsintech.co

events.name: Science Hack Day San Francisco 2012
events.about:
More details about Science Hack Day SF 2012 are at http://sf.sciencehackday.com

Press: If you are wanting to cover Science Hack Day SF, please email ariel@sciencehackday.org.

Attendees: Please only sign up if you intend to hack at Science Hack Day for BOTH days.

Science Hack Day is a 48-hour-all-night event that brings together designers, developers, scientists and other enthusiastic geeks in the same physical space for a brief but intense period of collaboration, hacking, and building 'cool stuff'. A hack is a unique modification, an interesting mashup or a quick solution to a problem - maybe not the most elegant solution, but often the cleverest. The mission of Science Hack Day is to "get excited and make things with science!" Here's what came out of last year's event: http://sf.sciencehackday.com/2011/11/22/summing-up-science-hack-day-sf-2011/

events.name: Altmetrics Hackathon
events.about:
Uncover how science research is shared, used, and measured with altmetrics at the Altmetrics Hackathon on Nov 3, 2012 in San Francisco.  Altmetrics are online metrics that capture the many ways in which research articles are shared, commented, reviewed, and put to use.  As a set, they collectively tell the larger story of science.

Build new tools and improve existing ones with real time datasets and API services.  Create new mashups.  Brainstorm the future of tracking science.  Fun prizes awarded at the end of the session.  View ideas and share your own here.

Co-hosted by PLOS and ImpactStory

events.name: Web Platform Documentation Sprint
events.about:
Web Platform Documentation Sprint- November 3rd, San Francisco

Web developer? Designer? Technical editor? Join like-minded individual contributors and help document the web platform—and improve thewebplatform.org user experience. This Doc Sprint is all about making it easy for anyone to contribute articles, samples, tutorials, overviews, and insights. Learn about webplatform.org, how to contribute, and help grow the definitive reference site for HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SVG and more.

WebPlatform.org is convened by W3C and is made possible by the support of the Web Platform Stewards.

Saturday, November 3rd

9:00AM - 9:30AM        Welcome Breakfast 
9:30AM-10:00AM        Introduction to Web Platform Docs
10:00AM - 1:00PM      Doc Sprint
1:00PM                        Lunch
1:00PM - 6:00PM        Doc Sprint
6:00PM - 7:00PM        Prizes & Dinner   

*Food catered by Indian Bento and vegetarian options will be available.

Location:

Adobe Systems Inc.

601 Townsend St.

San Francisco, CA

Train:

The Caltrain is a 10 minute walk from our facilities: http://www.caltrain.com/

San Francisco Station - 700 4th St., San Francisco 94107

Buses:

SF Muni Bus #10 passes by the Adobe Office en route to the Caltrain Depot, the Transbay Terminal, and Market St. Muni Bus #19 crosses Townsend at 8th Street traveling south. 

Parking:

There will be validated parking provided. Please pull a ticket upon entry into the garage. Lobby Reception and/or Security will validate your parking ticket. If you arrive after 7PM, you may need to buzz security to open the garage gate.

Adobe Garage
650 King St.
San Francisco, CA 94107
Map:  http://g.co/maps/fm3yu

Bicycles:

Secure bicycle storage is available but only on a first come first basis.

events.name: Foursquare Hackathon 2012: Connect all the Apps - SF
events.about:
The Foursquare hackathon is back! And this year, we’re inviting you to hack foursquare itself. Our all-new Connected Apps platform enables you to hack new functionality directly into the core Foursquare experience and make it discoverable to the over 25 million people already on foursquare.

On November 3rd, we’re opening up our NYC & SF offices for a connected apps hackathon of epic proportions. And just like last year, we’re inviting developers all around the world to band together and hack some awesome connected apps.

OMG Prizes

Oh yeah, and we're giving out some mindblowingly awesome prizes for the best connected apps built by anyone anywhere during the hackathon. Build something amazing and you might just find yourself ringing the NASDAQ closing bell, rockingtickets to SXSW, partying with an action figure version of yourself, or wearing the infamous foursquare hackathon TITLE BELT.

How Do I Do It?

  1. RSVP on our Meetup page
  2. If you're in NYC or SF, tell us a little bit about yourself for a reserved spot at an official site.
  3. Read the Schedule and Rules
  4. Mark your calendar and start thinking of ideas! We've got some suggestions to get your mental juices flowing.

events.name: Data DeathMatch!
events.about:
Data DeathMatch! Nov. 2rd/3rd, Fight Political Corruption and Help Schools Work Smarter!

Are you a hacker who wants to fight political corruption or thinks that our schools should work smarter? Choose your focus, work with our government allies, and join Code for America for a hackathon to improve the cities we live in.

 We’ve opened critical datasets (now available through well-documented APIs) and have lined up a blockbuster group of open-data advocates standing ready to help you build apps that will revolutionize the way citizens interact with government.

Want to get a head start? Here are the links for the education API and transparency data we'll be working with.


 

Friday, we'll break into hacker teams who want to work on government transparency data and those who want to hack education. Saturday, we'll go into full development mode and compete for use of our apps in government/schools and magical prizes! Along the way, the people who've developed the APIs (Captricity and LearnSprout) and our community partners who have shared their data (like the Fair Political Practices Commission (FPPC) and local school representatives) will have your back - providing you free coaching on how the data sets we'll be showcasing work.

Bonus: Prizes TBD. Beer, breakfast, lunch, and dinner! Ping pong and air hockey when you’re not hacking to save government or hearing from awesome speakers. 

Space is limited, so RSVP early.

Schedule
November 2nd: 

  • 6:30PM Mixer
  • 7PM Introduction of CfA, Community Stakeholder, APIs
  • 7:30PM Idea Development/Team Building
  • 8PM Wrap-up

November 3rd:

  • 9AM  Breakfast
  • 9:30AM Hackathon Overview
  • 10AM Work Sprint
  • 12PM Working Lunch
  • 1PM Work Sprint
  • 6PM  Dinner, Demos, Prizes
  • 7:30PM  Mixer

If you have questions, ping atran@codeforamerica.org. Sumo suits and wrestling attire strongly encouraged.

events.name: SOBA: Citizen Science
events.about:
SOBA: Citizen Science

Science Online Bay Area is all about how science is carried out and communicated online. As part of the Bay Area Science festival, SOBA opens up the debate to the larger community and addresses the question of citizen science with amateur scientists and professional researchers.

“DIY science”, “science hacking”, “citizen science” – these are just some of the many terms used to describe the experiments of amateur scientists, a trend that’s been evolving for more than 20 years. In garages, kitchens, and community labs, these “new” scientists shed light onto how science happens and occasionally contribute to exciting discoveries.  But how do they interact with professionals?  Science Online Bay Area and Swissnex San Francisco invite the public to attend a talk with citizen scientists and researchers to share their views on this new interface between science and society.

Presentations are followed by a panel discussion, audience Q&A, and follow-up conversation at a nearby bar (to be announced at the event). During the discussion portion of the evening, we’ll probe the challenges and opportunities of citizen science. Bring your questions!

*Presentations and discussion livestreamed. Follow the event on Twitter (@sciobayarea and #sobay), like SOBA on Facebook, and visit the ScienceOnline Bay Area blog for event recaps, news, and more.

Date: October 30th, 2012
Time: 7:00pm - 8:30pm
Location: swissnex San Francisco, 730 Montgomery Street, San Francisco, CA 94111

Speaker biographies

Ariel Waldman is the founder of Spacehack.org, a directory of ways to participate in space exploration, and the global instigator of Science Hack Day, an event that brings together scientists, technologists, designers and people with good ideas to see what they can create in one weekend. She is also an interaction designer, a research affiliate at Institute For The Future, and an advisor for the SETI Institute‘s radio show, Big Picture Science. Previously, she worked at NASA’s CoLab program whose mission was to connect communities inside and outside NASA to collaborate. Ariel has also been a sci-fi movie gadget columnist for Engadget and a digital anthropologist at VML. In 2008, she was named one of the top 50 most influential individuals in Silicon Valley. 

Amateur scientists, researchers and sociologists will also be part of the discussion.

events.name: Yammer's Hacktoberfest
events.about:
Hacktoberfest will bring together some of the best developers in the enterprise space, providing winners with an exclusive spot in Alchemist Accelerator, the leading incubator for enterprise startups, up to $5,000 in cash, an Xbox or the opportunity to present the hack at the YamJam conference. 

EVENT DETAILS:

Location:
Yammer HQ
410 Townsend, Suite 300
San Francisco, CA 94107

Sponsors:

Microsoft, Telesocial, Social+ Capital, Zencoder, and Micello

Prizes:

1st place prize: $5,000 + Presentation at YamJam Conference
2nd place prize: $1,000
Accelerator-Ready Team: Spot in the Alchemist Accelerator* & Xboxs for each member

Additionally, winners of hackers choice awards for Most Creative, Most Entertaining and Most Useful will receive Xboxs.  All winners receive trophies.

*Please note, because of limited space in Alchemist Accelerator (only 12 teams per year) this prize requires approval by 80% of Judges

Judging Criteria:

Each entry will be given three minutes to demo. No Powerpoint slides please! We just want to see your creations. We will judge you on the following critera:

  • Integration: How well does the application leverage the Yammer API?
  • Utility: How well does the application solve a real problem for end-users?
  • User Experience: How easy is the application to use?
  • Innovation: How creative and unique is the submission?

Agenda:

Saturday October 27th: 

  • 11am: Welcome & API Stand Ups
  • 12pm: Hacking begins
  • 1pm: Lunch is served
  • 6:30pm: Dinner is served
  • 11pm: Midnight snack

Sunday October 28th:

  • 9:30-10:30: Hack submissions due
  • 11:00: Presentations begin
  • 12:30 pm: Lunch is served
  • 1:30: Awards, celebration, send-off

events.name: API Hack Sunday
events.about:
Mashape is holding it's first Hackathon!

From 9AM-11PM on Sunday, October 21st we'll offer the food (amazing Italian Pasta handmade by the founders!), the drinks, and a $500 prize for best Mashape API hack! 

Bring your epic hacking skills and build something awesome together using Mashape APIs!

Schedule:

  • 9AM-10AM - Breakfast/Registration
  • 10AM - Demo by Stephen Balaban of Lambda Labs Facial Recognition API
  • 10AM-10:30PM - Hacking
  • 10:30-11:00PM - Judging

Lunch will be available from Noon-2PM for those who want a break. It is not required.

So come, join us! Free Food! Free Beer! $500 cash prize! Resistance is futile!

events.name: App.net Hackathon
events.about:
App.net Hackathon

 

Two days of developers collaborating (and, um, competing) to build the most imaginative, inspired, and innovative App.net apps. We'll provide the food, snacks, and ground rules, and you provide the ideas. Oh the possibilities.  

Saturday, October 20: 10 am – 10 pm (note we are not hacking through the night)

Sunday, October 21: 10 am – 4 pm

The day will start with an intro and overview from our ceo, Dalton Caldwell, and there will be a breakout session for those new to our API or who have questions on getting started.

App.net is an ad-free, subscirption based social network and API. For developers, we're a backbone you can rely on – the pipes you can build your web, mobile, and desktop apps on. Our API is here for you, and we won't shut you out.

Check out our GitHub for a comprehensive list of what apps have been built or are in development. You'll also find our API spec there too.  

Admission is free. If you're not in San Francisco, we'll try to set up some sort of video, so you don't miss out.

More details and agenda to come.

Hosted by our friends at Storify, who have already integrated App.net.

If you have questions, email support@app.net.

events.name: TAPPED NFC Hackathon
events.about:
TAPPED: The NFC Accelerator

Make your idea into a Near Field Communications reality! How about the chance to connect with some of the most influential people in mobile and NFC? How about the chance to win some major cash? Tap into that!

Visit our website at tappednfc.com for additional details, developer guide and NFC resources.

What it is

TAPPED: The NFC Accelerator is a collection of three free events, with one goal: drive innovation of novel NFC mobile app prototypes built on solid business plans.

Apps will need to focus on:

  • Social – Enhance, alter, and establish social interactions.
  • Gaming – Enrich games and possibly take them beyond the digital world and into the physical realm.
  • Internet of things – build bridges between the Android device and real-world objects. Leverage tools ranging from NFC tags, NFC-enabled appliances, or dedicated NFC-enabled devices built on Arduino and the Raspberry Pi minimal computing platforms.

Your app will need to run on Android, the leading smartphone platform for NFC development. Loaner devices will be available.,

Visual designers will be on hand to help with app user experience and graphics. You will also get a presentation template so you don’t need to worry about making your presentation to the judges look cool (you can still roll your own).

What you need

Naturally, bring your own computer. Save some time by installing the Android development tools in advance. We will give you a set of NFC gear (courtesy of Cellotape) – tags, wristbands, stickers, cards. We will also lend you one (or two) NFC phones if you don’t have one. It’s a Samsung Galaxy Nexus running Android 4.x. We’ll take care of food and drinks, too.

While we encourage you to take a very good look at our development guide, sample project and app code, expert Android and NFC developers will be on hand. We will also have a back-end developer on hand to assist with server-side matters (as well as folks from Kinvey, a nifty back-end as a service cloud offering we love).

Schedule

TAPPED tour events take place over the weekend and run from 10:30 am on Saturday through 6:30 pm Sunday. Coding will run from 11:30am Saturday through 3:00pm Sunday.

  • Saturday
    • 9:30 am – 10:30 am Registration
    • 10:30 am – 11:00 am Opening remarks
    • 11:00 am – 12:30 pm
      • Development begins
      • Breakout sessions about Android NFC development
      • Q&A with some of our API provider partners
    • 10:00 pm - You can continue coding but we have to leave the space
  • Sunday
    • 8:00 am - Back at General Assembly (breakfast)
    • 1:30 pm – 3:00 pm Judging presentation prep
    • 3:00 pm Coding ends
    • 3:00 pm – 4:30 pm Presentations to the judges
    • 4:30 pm – 5:00 pm Judges finalize decisions
    • 5:00 pm – 6:30 pm Award ceremony, drinks, finger foods

Very Important Note

Before we go any further we want to assure you: your code, ideas, thoughts remain YOUR OWN or property (or your team’s). You keep your code wherever you want and we will take it away from you.

Prizes and Rules

Winner Selection and Prizes

  • One winner will be selected for each one of the themes – Gaming, Social, Internet of things
  • Each of the three winners will then be ranked with each other to produce an overall winner, second place and a third place winner.
  • Prizes
    • First Place: $3000 plus $1000 for 3 months of hosting on Rackspace
    • Second Place: $2000 plus $500 for 3 months of hosting on Rackspace
    • Third Place: $1000 plus $250 for 3 months of hosting on Rackspace
  • Prizes will be distributed as American Express gift cards.

Event winners from all three events will be invited to submit their work to Verizon’s NFC challenge, part of Verizon’s participation in this year’s premier NFC industry event, WIMA. The Verizon NFC Challenge winners will be invited to join Verizon in San Francisco, CA, November 26-27, 2012 to present their apps.

Gift Cards

Gift cards will be sent to users following the event. That way if you have a team of three you won’t need to find a way to split a $3,000 gift card.

TAPPED Rules

  1. All coding and development must take place during the event and on event premises.
  2. Competition entries can be from single developers or from teams of 2-4 developers.
  3. Competition entries will be presented and must run on a device provided at the event.
  4. Event participants must be willing to show their code to event staff and able to demonstrate it compiles in an Android development environment.
  5. All code developed during the event will remain the sole property of its developers.
    Competition entries must be related to one of the three themes of the events
    • Gaming
    • Social
    • Internet of Things
  6. Apps must run on an Android device and use NFC in their operation.
  7. Apps developed during the event will not be secret or confidential. We will use the apps in our publicity materials.
  8. Winners will provide the Event organizers with a working Android app apk file for demonstration purposes in publicity functions. We will not distribute the app but want to have the ability to remember what you created.

Judging Guidelines

  1. Working App – the app must be working and demonstrated on the device during the presentation (25%)
  2. NFC Use – The app must use NFC as a key element in its functionality. (25%)
  3. Relevance to the the application theme – The app must relate to one of the following: social, gaming or Internet of things. An app can cross boundaries but cannot be disconnected from the themes. (15%)
  4. Originality – the app bringing something novel to life? (15%)
  5. Business prospects – Is the app built with a business model in mind? (10%)
  6. Look and feel – How well does the app look and work? (10%)

Our Sponsors

events.name: Inbox Love Hacks!
events.about:
Inbox Love 2 is upon us on October 24th, and to kick off the event with a bang, Context.IO and SendGrid are hosting the first ever Inbox Love Hacks! 

This event will be all about email and the amazing app platform it provides. Join us to build productivity, analytics, collaboration, customer relationship and document management applications that can really lighten everyone's load and give us time to focus on the more important things in life. 

We're opening this up to all developers with an interest in email, regardless of whether or not you'll be at Inbox Love in Mountain View on the 24th. 

SCHEDULE

8:30 AM: Arrival, networking and breakfast

9 AM: API demos, idea generation and team creation where needed 

9:30 AM: BUILD AMAZING THINGS ON EMAIL

12:00: Yummy lunch served (no need to stop building amazing things, just pick up some food and get back to it!)

1:00: CONTINUE TO BUILD AMAZING THINGS ON EMAIL

4:30: DEMOS BEGIN!

BEERS

5:45: Top 3 winners announced... they'll go on to demo at Inbox Love in Mountain View on October 24th to a seriously esteemed panel of email experts. 

6:00: It's a wrap!

More surprises to be announced soon... get on board ASAP, capacity is limited... but possbilities are endless!

events.name: Adobe Game Jam- San Francisco
events.about:
Adobe Game Jam
San Francisco – Oct 19th and 20th

Are you into building Games? Do you want to show your gaming coding skills, have fun, and win some cool prizes? The come join us October 19th & 20th for the first Adobe Game Jam.  You’ll meet likeminded people and learn more about Flash game design and development.

Rules:  http://gaming.adobe.com/events/gamejams/

Prizes

12-month subscription to Adobe Creative Cloud®

Participants will vote for winners in each of the following categories:

  • Game concept and design
  • Technology
  • Graphics

Requirements

  • You will need to bring your own equipment (laptop and/or devices ) to build and demo the game. (There will be limited set of devices available on-site for testing and presenting your game)
  • You should be somewhat familiar with programming in ActionScript 3.
  • To save time, either Flash Builder 4.7 beta (free download) or Flash Professional CS6 (free 30-day trial available) are recommended to already be installed on your laptop before the Game Jame begins.
  • Wi-Fi will be provided

Schedule


Friday, October 19th

4:00PM       
 Registration/Meet & Greet
4:30PM Introduction: Demo of Stage 3D apps for iOS/Android + Desktop and a basic walkthough of available engines and tooling.
 5-7:00PM Brainstorm & Teams: You can work solo or form a team of up to 5 members.  Experts will be on hand to help you implement a plan for Saturday’s coding.







*Snacks and beverages will be provided

Saturday, October 20th

9:00AM        Check -in (Coffee & breakfast will be provided)
9:30AM Start coding! Experts will be on hand to answer questions and help troubleshoot.
12:30PM

Break for Lunch (Pizza from Amici’s)
 6:00PM All Games Finalized
 6-7:00PM Game Showcase
  Teams present games (5 min each)
  Attendees vote on games
  Winners & Prizes announced

 

 



 

 

  

Location:

Adobe Systems Inc.

601 Townsend St.

San Francisco, CA

Train:

The Caltrain is a 10 minute walk from our facilities: http://www.caltrain.com/

San Francisco Station - 700 4th St., San Francisco 94107

Buses:

SF Muni Bus #10 passes by the Adobe Office en route to the Caltrain Depot, the Transbay Terminal, and Market St. Muni Bus #19 crosses Townsend at 8th Street traveling south. 

Parking:

There will be validated parking provided. Please pull a ticket upon entry into the garage. Lobby Reception and/or Security will validate your parking ticket. If you arrive after 7PM, you may need to buzz security to open the garage gate.

Adobe Garage
650 King St.
San Francisco, CA 94107
Map:  http://g.co/maps/fm3yu

Bicycles:

Secure bicycle storage is available but only on a first come first basis.

events.name: Big Data and Bigger Data Science
events.about:
Thursday, October 18th from 7:00 - 8:00 pm

Team of founders & early employees, Keen.io

This class is in preparation for the ReRoute/SF hackathon happening at the Hattery on Oct. 19-21st. 

From browsers to mobile applications and from cars to printers, we live in an age of an internet of things. Every access point presents an opportunity to learn a great deal about what users want. Successful companies will require flexible and extensible technology as well as resident data scientists to make the most of this connected world. This class is both a primer on big data data science and the technology that will support it. 

Student Takeaways:

Folks will leave the class with an appreciation for how developers and business stakeholders can leverage user analytics in building and optimizing mobile applications. Students will also get early access to Keen's analytics platform, as well as a tutorial on the service. 

Level & Prerequisites:

Beginner. The class is an introduction to data science and how a wise integration can drive dollars and customer experience. The July 2011 New Yorker article, “Looking for Someone”, is a fun primer on data science. It’ll help set the mood. 

Required class materials / software:

A laptop and curiosity. We’ll be using Keen’s cloud-based platform to run through some exercises on a provided data set. We'll also talk quickly about feeding new data into the system, in case we have any experienced developers. 

Instructor bio:

Keen is all about the team. A handful of the founders and early employees will be onsite to teach and support. Professional backgrounds include Google, Salesforce.com, iFixIt, Accenture, and Amazon. Apparel choices will range from pressed shirts to skinny jeans.


Offered in partnership with the  . 

___

Can't make it? Sign up at http://generalassemb.ly/sf to stay in the loop on future events and classes in San Francisco. Follow us on Twitter @GA_SF. 
 

 

INSTRUCTOR NAME

events.name: Life is a Game: A Weekend Long Game Jame hosted by Class Dojo
events.about:
Life is a Game San Francisco – Oct 13th and 14th
Join us for a weekend long Game Jam hosted by Class Dojo. You'll meet awesome new people, test your production skills and hear from some of the most creative people in the game industry. 

How does this work?
Teams of 4-6 people will make games around a central theme announced Saturday morning. You can bring a team with you or form a team during pitches. Just bring your ideas and your own technology, we'll provide prizes, meals, snacks and drinks. There will be office space available if you want to crash onsite  or you can go home for the night, it's up to you.
 
Judging
Submissions will be reviewed by panelists from Artillery Games, Red Hot Labs and Phoenix Guild. Prizes will be awarded for:

Best Overall
Best Use of Theme
The Oddball
 
Schedule
Saturday
9:00am - 9:30am: Check in
9:30am - 10:00am: Tech Talks and theme announced
10:00am - 11:30am: Pitches and team forming
11:00pm Doors are locked for the night

Rest of Saturday: Make games

Sunday
1:00pm - 2:00pm: Wrap up and prepare presentations
3:00pm - 3:45pm: Team presenations
4:15pm - 5:00pm: Winners announced!

events.name: friday night swap/meet: ArtHackMeetery
events.about:
In the Bay Area, we are bombarded with info about hackathons, unhackathons, meetups, and more for coders, entrepreneurs, designers, and more to collaborate and solve problems ... but where are the artists?

With ArtHackMeetery, we want to bring together civically minded artists to brainstorm and prototype ways to improve their urban landscape using their unique perspectives as artists.

 With so many artists working in this space, it seems prime time to get together, make stuff, and drink some beers. Teams of artists will work together to (quickly, like really quickly) brainstorm and prototype solutions to various civic issues specific to the Central Market neighborhood. After the teams present their concepts, there will be time for more drinks and conversation.

We hope you will join us!

Note that the program begins at 7:00pm. 

---

About swap/meet:

Chris Treggiari’s artistic practice strives to investigate how art can penetrate the public realm in a way that connects wide ranges of people and neighborhoods in a variety of communities. Chris’s public installations aim to turn the passive viewer into an active art maker. Some of his most recent projects, like the Mobile Arts Platform and War Gastronomy, have been shown at the 2012 Venice Architecture Biennale, the Berkeley Art Museum, the Torrance Art Museum, SOMArts and the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts.

Jessica Watson is a recent graduate of the MBA in Design Strategy program at CCA. Since she can remember, she has been interested in how the intersection of creativity and the city can help to solve urban issues. She has worked with the Mayor’s Office for Civic Innovation, fuseproject and Hot Studio. Additionally, she is a frequent contributor and/or collaborator to Chris Treggiari’s projects, including All Aboard as part of Southern Exposure’s Public Art/Urban Intervention Day.

events.name: OSS illumos hackathon
events.about:
As the OpenStorage Summit is being rescheduled (I don't have further details: it's a marketing event, whereas I'm an engineer), I am pleased to announce that Joyent is picking up this event as part of illumos/ZFS day.

Here's the revised format thus far: projects discussions may commence as a wind-down for ZFS Day (October 2), so it can't hurt to be on hand for both.

Coding will happen the following day. Demos will start at 5 and give way to whatever socialising people have left in them at that point.

events.name: Saturday Hack 4 Good
events.about:
TechSoup Global is hosting a Saturday Hack 4 Good!

Inspired by the Social Good Summit and Hackathon beginning the same day in New York City, our Saturday Hack 4 Good  is planned for September 22nd. Here are the key details:

  • Time: 11:30am - 6pm
  • Date: 9/22/12
  • Place: 525 Brannan Street, San Francisco.

Whether you’re a hacker, designer, nonprofit representative -- or someone with a great idea for creating innovative apps for good  -- we’d love for you to join us. There will be lunch, beer and prizes.  Just bring your good ideas and your laptop!

Join us and let’s hack for good!

events.name: Big Data and APIs Hackathon
events.about:
AngelHack Events and the Data Week Conference would like to invite you to the first ever Big Data and APIs Hackathon.

This will be one of the first hackathons to allow you to build upon existing code, thus allowing teams to win prizes for integrating Big Data Tools, like New Relic, into their current companies. Don't worry code monkeys, we also have prizes for those of you looking to hack things from scratch too :)

Interested in Big Data? Come learn tools from some of the best in the business that will help you simplify things and make sense of the madness.

Not interested in Big Data? We'll have a couple great non Big Data APIs for you to work on to. Come enjoy the food, the people, and the great amenities that AngelHack Events are known for.

Wondering what to expect? Great food -Check! Great Prizes -Check! Complimentary Masseuses -Check! T-shirts -Check! Hackathon toys -Check! A shit ton of people to hack through the night with -Check! Let's do this!!! 

Note- This is not an AngelHack, but an AngelHack Event -- Brought to you by the same great team that brings you the largest hackathons in the world. Interested sponsors can email greg@angelhack.com

events.name: Startup Weekend San Francisco 9/21 - 9/23
events.about:
For all event details, visit swbay.startupweekend.org

Things to bring and remember:

1. Bring a laptop

2. Bring headphones if you need to drown out all the noise while working

3. We have a ton of monitors at the site, so bring a VGA or DVI cable if you want to hook up your laptop

4. Parking really sucks at this location. We recommend BART or MUNI. We are also on a moderate hill, so be prepared for a bit of exercise. 

 

 

Thanks!

Startup Weekend Crew

 

Refund Policy:  No refunds will be granted within 7 days of the event if food and drink have already been ordered. Apologies for any inconvenience this may cause.

About Startup Weekend: Startup Weekends are 54-hour events designed to provide superior experiential education for technical and non-technical entrepreneurs.  Beginning with Friday night pitches and continuing through brainstorming, business plan development, and basic prototype creation, Startup Weekends culminate in Sunday night demos and presentations.  Participants create working startups during the event and are able to collaborate with like-minded individuals outside of their daily networks. All teams hear talks by industry leaders and receive valuable feedback from local entrepreneurials. The weekend is centered around action, innovation, and education.  Whether you are looking for feedback on a idea, a co-founder, specific skill sets, or a team to help you execute, Startup Weekends are the perfect environment in which to test your idea and take the first steps towards launching your own startup.

events.name: THack @ SFO
events.about:
The showcase for the Tnooz THack @ SFO developer hackathon will take place at San Francisco International Airport.

Developers will present their hacks in front of fellow competing developers, industry peers and others at the event.

Tnooz has assembled a blue ribbon panel of judges to help select an overall winner. Refreshments will be served!

More details about THack @ SFO available.

********

THack @ SFO will be followed immediately by the latest monthly meet-up of the San Francisco TravelMassive, in the same venue. More details here.

events.name: Hacks/Hackers Hacking @ ONA12
events.about:
Journalists, developers and designers: Register today for the third annual Hacks/Hackers Hacking @ ONA!

This year's event will be on Sept. 20, at Storify headquarters in SoMa. Meet new people, make new friends and work on those projects you've been thinking about.

What we produce together at the hack day will help shape the future of news and civic information.

Hacks/Hackers will provide food, snacks and beverages from local establishments to keep you going as you collaborate and prototype your ideas.

Don't miss out! Register now.

Hacks/Hackers Hacking is made possible with support from:

 



 


Interested in co-sponsoring Hacks/Hackers Hacking? Get in touch!
